display.label: Microsoft SharePoint
display.description: Interact with sites, drives, and items connected to your instance of Microsoft SharePoint.

connections.label: Microsoft SharePoint OAuth 2.0
connections.comments: Authenticates actions in the Microsoft SharePoint component.

inputs.comments: Provide a tenant specific OAuth 2.0 authorize endpoint.
inputs.label: Authorize URL

inputs.comments: Provide a tenant specific OAuth 2.0 token endpoint.
inputs.label: Token URL

inputs.comments: Space separated OAuth 2.0 permission scopes
inputs.label: Scopes

inputs.comments: Client Id of your Azure application
inputs.label: Client ID

inputs.comments: Client Secret generated under 'Certificates & Secrets' in your Azure application.
inputs.label: Client Secret

documentation.description:
Once you have an instance of Microsoft SharePoint licensed to your account, you will need to create and configure a new "App Registration" within your [Azure Active Directory tenant](https://portal.azure.com/#home).
When creating the application you will be prompted to select the 'Supported account types'. Under this section, be sure to select 'Accounts in any organizational directory (Any Azure AD directory - Multitenant)'.

You will need to go to "Platforms" and add the "Web" platform. In that section you should add Prismatic's OAuth 2.0 callback URL - https<!---->://oauth2.prismatic.io/callback - as a **Redirect URI**.

Next, go to "Certificates & Secrets" for the app and add a new **Client Secret**. Note this value as you will need to supply it to the connection within Prismatic.

You will also need the **Application (client) ID** from the "Overview" page.

The last step of configuring the "App Registration" is assigning "App Permissions". Click "Add Permission", click on the square labeled "SharePoint", and then "Delegated permissions". You should select all permissions that are required for your desired integration.

Now, configure the OAuth 2.0 connection in Prismatic.
Add an MS SharePoint OAuth 2.0 connection config variable:

-   Use the **Application (client) ID** value for the **Client ID** field.
-   Use the **Client Secret** for the same named field.
-   If you didn't select Multitenant when creating the Azure application, you will need to replace the **Authorize URL** and **Token URL** with ones specific to your tenant.

Save your integration and you should be able to authenticate a user through MS SharePoint with OAuth 2.0.

inputs.comments: Provide the unique identifier of a SharePoint site.
inputs.label: Site Id

inputs.comments: Provide the unique identifier of a SharePoint site list.
inputs.label: List Id

inputs.comments: URL to send events of this Subscription to
inputs.label: Notification URL

inputs.comments: Expiration date/time for subscription. If unspecified the default will be the current date/time plus 29 days (close to the maximum permitted by the Graph API).
inputs.label: Expiration Date/Time

inputs.comments: Enable to allow more than one webhook per endpoint
inputs.label: Allow Duplicates

display.label: Update Site List Subscription Expiration
display.description: Update existing Site List subscription expiration for Microsoft SharePoint

inputs.comments: Subscription ID to manage
inputs.label: Subscription ID

inputs.comments: Expiration date/time for subscription. If unspecified the default will be the current date/time plus 29 days (close to the maximum permitted by the Graph API).
inputs.label: Expiration Date/Time

documentation.description: [Subscriptions have an expiration date/time](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/resources/subscription?view=graph-rest-1.0#maximum-length-of-subscription-per-resource-type) provided upon creation. This can also be modified with the update API. This action will default to adding 29 days (close to the maximum value for SharePoint resources) to the current date/time unless a value is specified. This is useful for "touching" the subscription to ensure its expiration is extended.

display.label: Create a Subscription
display.description: Create a Subscription to notify you of changes to a resource

inputs.comments: The type of changes that should generate notifications for this subscription. OneDrive only supports updated.
inputs.label: Change Type

inputs.comments: The URL that notifications should be delivered to, if required for the specified notificationType.
inputs.label: Notification URL

inputs.comments: The relative path of the subscription within the drive. Read-only.
inputs.label: Resource

inputs.comments: The date and time when the subscription will expire if not updated or renewed.
inputs.label: Expiration Date Time

inputs.comments: An optional string value that is passed back in the notification message for this subscription.
inputs.label: Client State

inputs.comments: Enable to allow more than one subscription per endpoint
inputs.label: Allow Duplicates

display.label: Raw Request
display.description: Send a raw HTTP request to Microsoft Sharepoint's API

inputs.comments: Input the path only (/me/followedSites), The base URL is already included (https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0). For example, to connect to https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me/followedSites, only /me/followedSites is entered in this field.
inputs.label: URL

inputs.comments: The HTTP method to use.
inputs.label: Method

inputs.comments: The HTTP body payload to send to the URL.
inputs.label: Data

inputs.comments: The Form Data to be sent as a multipart form upload.
inputs.label: Form Data

inputs.comments: File Data to be sent as a multipart form upload.
inputs.label: File Data

inputs.placeholder: The file name to apply to a file
inputs.comments: File names to apply to the file data inputs. Keys must match the file data keys above.
inputs.label: File Data File Names

inputs.comments: A list of query parameters to send with the request. This is the portion at the end of the URL similar to ?key1=value1&key2=value2.
inputs.label: Query Parameter

inputs.comments: A list of headers to send with the request.
inputs.label: Header

inputs.comments: The type of data you expect in the response. You can request json, text, or binary data.
inputs.label: Response Type

inputs.comments: The maximum time that a client will await a response to its request
inputs.label: Timeout

inputs.comments: Enabling this flag will log out the current request.
inputs.label: Debug Request

inputs.comments: The delay in milliseconds between retries.
inputs.label: Retry Delay (ms)

inputs.comments: If true, retries on all erroneous responses regardless of type.
inputs.label: Retry On All Errors

inputs.comments: The maximum number of retries to attempt.
inputs.label: Max Retry Count

inputs.comments: Specifies whether to use a pre-defined exponential backoff strategy for retries.
inputs.label: Use Exponential Backoff

display.label: List Changes
display.description: Track changes in a driveItem and its children over time.

inputs.comments: The URL to track changes in a driveItem and its children over time. You can also paste here the @odata.nextLink or @odata.deltaLink from a previous response to resume tracking changes.
inputs.label: URL to fetch for delta

inputs.comments: Filters properties (columns). https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/query-parameters?tabs=http#select-parameter
inputs.label: $select Parameter

inputs.comments: Retrieves related resources. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/query-parameters?tabs=http#expand-parameter
inputs.label: $expand Parameter

inputs.comments: Sets the page size of results.	https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/query-parameters?tabs=http#top-parameter
inputs.label: $top Parameter

display.label: List Sites from Sharepoint
display.description: A picklist of Sites

documentation.description:
[Microsoft SharePoint](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/sharepoint/collaboration?ms.officeurl=sharepoint&rtc=1) is a web-based collaborative platform that integrates with Microsoft Office.
This component allows you to interact with your sites, drives, and items by making queries through the Microsoft Graph API.
